Images are omnipresent in biomedical science [link history] but their understandability [link PLOS] and quality [link misleading] is often subpar. To truthfully report qualitative observations abd quantify observations images need to be properly processed. As images are digital data, the sequence and software of image processing matters.

## Image Workflow for Novice Users
We have therefore compiled a easy to follow workflow to get from microscope to published image in simple steps. At the moment, only few scientists are trained in microscopy and image handling and only few research institutes have dedicated facilities – this means there is a great need in introductory level information.

## Cheat Sheets
The workflow is summarised in two printable cheat sheets. One cheat sheet explains the steps towards a publishable image, the second cheat sheet how to implement the steps with ImageJ/FIJI image processing software.

## Further resources
Beyond out cheat sheet there several specialized resources: 
The “Biologist’s guide to planning and performing quantitative bioimaging experiments” describes the entire arc from sample to microscope via image analysis towards data interpretation and publication. The resource lists many key points and aggregates links to more detailed descriptions, making it easy for biologists to navigate their first microscopy experiments. 
<ul>
<li>A biologist’s guide to planning and performing quantitative bioimaging experiments. <a href = "https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pbio.3002167">Senft RA, Diaz-Rohrer B, Colarusso P, Swift L, Jamali N, Jambor H, et al. (2023) PLoS Biol</a> </li>
</ul>
